captions.text:
Facebook recently unveiled a second URL for
their site that can only be accessed through

TOR, which is a software that allows users
to log-in anonymously from nearly anywhere
on

the planet - even in countries where Facebook
is heavily monitored or blocked. This makes

Facebook the first major web company to offer
a platform on the dark web. So, what is the
dark
web and why did Facebook join it?

First off, it’s important to understand
that the internet is vast and constantly growing,
and

the majority of our daily usage only scratches
the surface. Google, Yahoo, and other search

engines only show about 4% of the data available
on the internet. To access the other 96%

requires customized digging through individual
sites, subpages, restricted access journals
or

archives, and so on. This 96% is called the
“deep web.”

It’s also important to understand that pretty
much everything we do online is visible,

traceable, and possibly being monitored. Everything
except... for the areas of the deep web that
are masked by the “dark web.”

The “dark web” is concealed through a
series of identity masking layers, which basically

means that you can access and interact with
it anonymously without being tracked. This
is

achieved through special encryption software
like TOR, an acronym for The Onion Router,

which when installed on your computer, appears
and acts like your standard Firefox browser,

albeit slower. But instead of routing your
connection through a direct line, TOR routes

everything through a series of encrypted computers
all over the world, bouncing around

randomly before it reaches its host destination.
This makes the origin of the data and the
people

searching for it, unknowable. So while you
might actually be in New York, your search
traffic

can appear to be coming from random points
all over the world, making your location essentially
untraceable.

So why does Facebook, a company that is anything
but anonymous or discreet, want this?

Well, they claim that it’s all part of a
long term effort to achieve greater “accessibility
and

security” for its users - which according
to some critics, is pretty much just code
for desired

global domination. Facebook wants to be used
by everyone, everywhere. And pushing the site

into the dark web opens Facebook up to users
who might otherwise be unable to access it,
or

might worry about government surveillance
or other security controls or threats. Places
like Iran

or China, for example, are known to restrict
access to social sites, like facebook. TOR
won’t

shield users’ Facebook profiles or activities
-- those will still be public -- but it will
keep their

location and potentially their real identity,
hidden from the authorities.

If you’d like to learn more about the inner
workings of the web, check out this DNews
video

on How the Internet Works. (Sound up.) And
if you have ideas for topics or questions
you’d like

us to explore, let us know on Facebook or
in the comments down below. Thanks for watching.

comments.text:
Assuming the NSA has access to all Facebook logs, and I think you'd be 
ignorant to assume they don't, if someone logs into TOR and then their 
Facebook account it would then put a name and a location of that person to 
all Dark Web activities until they exit TOR. Why? Because if that person 
has ever logged into their Facebook account using a non-TOR system then the 
NSA will know where that person lives based on ISP IP address logs. Maybe 
this is just one more way that the NSA will identify and locate people on 
the Dark Web.﻿

comments.text:
+Jamie Owns oh. i like your idealism. but i wonder... who says they should 
do this? you? god? the universe? Its easy to point fingers at others and 
say "THEY'RE the evil ones! Kill them! (or whatever)" until the point where 
you realize the one being pointed at is you. I'm not condoning what any 
single person, group of people, or a government does nor am i condemning. 
I'm just saying, its easy to be standing on the sidelines and complain from 
your (not specifically you but whatever) "high horse" but in all honesty 
what would you do about it? Do you even have an idea about whats going? and 
not what one side or another says, but what really is going on? Of you 
course don't have all the facts because you're biased on one side of the 
argument when there is twelve million different factions...If i've learned 
anything from my time apart from humanity, and my many years as a gamer, 
its this:
1. Everything is relative. Who what when where how and why are the 
questions you ask... but do you ever really have an answer?
2. History is created by the victors. Who ever won, or caused someone to 
win, has bragging rights... basically the history of war in general has 
been a huge bragging contest between winners.
3. Humans are a very subjective species. More so that they think "morals" 
and "ethics" is a natural thing... no its never been that simple the more 
you believe it is the harder and colder this life will be. and for some 
reason they think of "darkness" as evil when that's not the case.
4.Our minds are able to achieve seemingly impossible feats...but we hold 
ourselves back.
and stick with me now...
5. I think we all fight for this truth justice liberty freedom and, for 
some, or gods beliefs and cultural because deep down we all want some sort 
of absolution. "if i do this right then i'll be rewarded, loved and 
praised, instead of condemn hated and punished" kind of that...which is a 
good thought, but when one societies ideas collide with another... well 
that's when war happens. 
absolution...its not a bad thing i guess, but in order for us to move into 
the future we must be able to realize that we don't have all the answers. 
but we'd be damned to oblivion if we didn't try to find them. whelp that's 
my thought at least. 
Basically its not about morals or ethics or whats right or wrong, its about 
how the human mind works. once we crack that code... well we've figured out 
one of our biggest mysteries. Ourselves
comments.author: HaseoOkami

comments.text:
Yes I do. Well obviously this is nothing more than my personal opinion. 
When a government agency like NSA hacks into peoples computers there seen 
as protecting there citizens, but when a hacker hacks in to computers there 
seen as bad people that break the law even if there intentions were 
harmless. They use drones to kill innocent people with out any evidence to 
say that these people were really terrorists. The government have no right 
in using drones or any other kind of warfare to kill people in other 
countries yet they do. If a normal person just kills one person they are 
seen worse than any drone attack that kills loads of innocent people. How 
exactly can you define what laws are, when the same people that make them 
laws break them. Not saying that we should get rid of laws. Just saying 
that government should obey the same laws and be held accountable equally 
when broken. If breaking the law makes you bad then governments would be 
the worst of all. Governments kill people on mass scale they do all kinds 
of other morally wrong stuff that would make them worse than the bad people 
working on small scale. Both are bad and both should be held accountable to 
the people that they harm.

comments.author: AsianSensation Studios

comments.text:
Aweful episode!
Real world Tor/ Dark web metaphor:
Tor just forwards internet data (you can imagine it as letters!). Instead 
of sending it to facebook you send it to tor and tor sends it to facebook. 
Thus the letter you send out has "tor" as destination not facebook. Thus 
you hide the actualy address. No dark web involved just the normal web... 
The word might sound fancy but doesn't make any sense. Just because someone 
forwards letters for you it makes your destination part of a "dark earth" 
!?!? nope ... still earth.

Real world deep web metaphor:
Imagine your internet address is a real house address.
You hate the spam in your postbox every morning so you remove your address 
from the phone book/yellow pages (Google) and only tell your friends where 
you life. Congratulation you are now part of the "deep earth" ... nope ... 
still earth. but at least this term makes some kind of sense. But why would 
my webpage not count as the normal web/internet just by making sure it 
isn't listed in the google search results?!?﻿
